resources.string: No applications are autostarting within your current selection.

Please note: If you have trouble with Autostarts hanging while trying to disable or enable an application, please be sure to activate the \"USB Debugging\" option in your device settings under \"Applications -> Development\".\n\nIt\'s a bug in the Superuser Whitelist application that will hopefully be fixed in a future version.
You are about to disable a system component. This could potentially result in your phone no longer functioning properly.\n\nDo not proceed unless you are willing to deal with the consequences.
Unable to change the state of the selected component.\n\nMost likely, your device does not have root access, which is required.

How does it work?

Android allows applications to register for a variety of events supported by the system, to be started whenever such an event triggers.

This allows applications to do important work in the background, but may sometimes also slow down the system.

Autostarts helps you keep control over your phone by letting you know what goes on behind your back.


Can I remove an application from a particular event?

Yes, but due to Android API limitations, it only works on rooted devices. Please be careful when disabling stuff. In particular note that the component in question may be responsible for other parts of the application's functionality than just the given event. As a result, you may experience unintended side effects. For the most part though, you can just give things a try, and enable the component again should the application break.


Autostarts is freezing when I try to disable something.

This is a bug in the Åžuperuser Whitelist app that comes with most ROMs. You need to activate the "USB Debugging" option in your device settings under "Applications -> Development".


Is it possible to know what a particular application does on a particular event?

No, not per se. However, if you select an entry, you will be able to see what the name of the component is that handles the event. Sometimes, the name gives you a hint. For example, an AlarmInitReceiver would likely initialize the alarms or notification that you have enabled in the application. Don't be surprised then if this application's alarms stop working if you disable the component.


I've disabled a component, but it seems to have it self enabled again after a while?

Yes, applications may enable or disable their own components. Some do this depending on settings, or what features are enabled. Unfortunately, there is no workaround for this.


My market downloads stopped working.

This is usually not the fault of Autotstarts, don't get ideas. However, there is one issue you might have run into. If you thought you weren't using Google Talk anyway and disabled it's On Boot event, this is likely to be the problem (it also occurs of you shutdown Google Talk using a task manager). Apparently, for some reason, if Google Talk is not running, market downloads do not work.
Close help and return to app
Airplane mode was switched on or off.
The charging state, or the charge level of the battery has changed.
The device entered a low battery state.
The device left the low battery state.
The device is booting up, the user cannot interact yet.
The device just completed booting up, the user can now interact.
External power has been connected to the device.
External power has been removed from the device.
The device was docked or undocked.
Due to a user action, the system asks a temporary system dialog to be dismissed.
The device configuration changed. This includes things like locale settings, but also the device orientation.
The device\'s locale setting has changed. This is a subset of \"Configuration changed\".
The device storage space has passed below a certain threshold.
The device storage space has increased beyond the critical threshold, and the low memory condition no longer exists.
A wired headset was either plugged in or unplugged.
The input method engine changed, i.e. the virtual keyboard in use.
The user acknowledged a \"low memory\" notification, and the package management is about to be started.
External media was removed, but not correctly unmounted.
The \"Media Button\" was pressed. Usually, this will refer to a button on your headset/earplugs.
External media is present and is currently being disk-checked.
External media is about to be ejected, likely due to a user request.
External media is present, was mounted and is now available to the device.
External media was detected, but is using an incompatible filesystem or is blank.
External media was just removed, and is now no longer available to the device.
The media scanner has finished scanning a directory.
The media scanner has started to scan a file and add it to the media database.
The media scanner has started scanning a directory.
External media is now being shared via USB mass storage mode, and is at this time no longer available to the device.
External media was detected, but cannot be used, likely due to an error.
External media is available, but unmounted, and not available to the device.
A new outgoing call is about to be placed. Applications may preprocess the call, and for example change or filter the phone number.
A new application package has been installed on the device.
An application package has been changed; for example, a component may have been enabled or disabled.
The user data associated with an application package was cleared.
An application is about to be downloaded and installed.
An application package has been removed from the device.
An application package has been replaced by a new version.
An application package was restarted, and all it\'s processes have been killed.
A content provider publishes a new event; for example, this is triggered by the GMail Storage provider when the set of unread email in the inbox changes.
The system is about to reboot.
The system timezone setting has changed.
The current time has changed. This is triggered once every minute.
A user id was removed from the system. This is usually related to the removal of an installed application.
The device has entered USB Mass Storage mode.
The device has exited USB Mass Storage mode.
The user woke up the device and successfully passed the keyguard (if enabled).
The system wallpaper has changed, either due to a user action, or by an application.
The SIM storage for SMS messages is full.
A new text based SMS message has been received.
A new data SMS message has been received.
A text based SMS message has been rejected.
A new WAP PUSH message has been received.
The network IDs of the configured networks may have changed.
The Wi-Fi signal strength (RSSI) has changed.
An access point scan has completed, and results are available.
The state of Wi-Fi connectivity has changed.
The connection to a Wi-Fi access point was either successfully established, or an existing connection lost.
The state of of establishing a connection to an access point has changed.
The ringer mode has changed (silent, vibrate, etc).
The vibrate setting has changed (on, off, etc).
Audio is about to become \'noisy\' due to a change in audio outputs, e.g. when a headset is unplugged.
The TextToSpeech synthesizer has completed processing of all the text in the speech queue.
Signals the completion of the installation of the data files used by the synthesis engine.
The setting for background data usage has changed values.
The first copy of a widget was added.

A widget is asked to update itself. How often this is triggered depends on the widget in question, but never for widgets that are not in use.\n\nNote that disabling this event will likely render the widget defunct.
The last copy of a widget was removed.
A copy of a widget was removed. Note that most widgets support multiple copies.
The call state of the phone has changed, for example when a new call is coming in, a call is accepted, or a previously active call ends.

The current network connection has changed, e.g. when switching from Wi-Fi to GSM. Note that since this is also triggered when a connection is initially established, it effectively entails the "On Startup" behavior.
A new photo was added to the gallery, usually by the Camera application after the user made a new photo.
A "secret code" was entered in the dialer. They are in the form of "*#*##*#*".
The name of the network operator or service provider have changed.
An application is not responding. This is when you see the infamous dialog box.
A reminder for a scheduled event should now be shown. This is used by the Calendar application.
An application wants to put a shortcut on your home screen. Home screen application will usually register for this.
An application wants to remove a shortcut from your home screen. Home screen application will usually register for this.
The state of a data connection (for example MMS, GPS) has changed, for example when you connect to a new APN.
The phone\'s service state has changed, for example when you start roaming, or connect to a different mobile network.
An attempt to establish a data connection has failed.
The sim card state has changed, for example when it is initially loaded, or when it becomes locked due to incorrect PIN entry.
The phone\'s signal strength has changed.
The phone\'s time was set by the carrier.
The phone\'s timezone was set by the carrier.
The state of the Wi-Fi chip has changed, for example when it is enabled or disabled.
